runningMethods.title: High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT)
runningMethods.description: Alternates short bursts of near-maximal/explosive anaerobic effort with brief recovery periods; sessions usually under 30 minutes.
runningMethods.origin: Early 20th century athletic training; systemized across modalities, including running and cycling.

runningMethods.title: Tabata Protocol
runningMethods.description: 20 seconds of ultra-intense effort (~170% VO₂max), followed by 10 seconds rest, repeated eight times (total 4 minutes).
runningMethods.origin: Developed in Japan in the mid-1990s by Dr. Izumi Tabata for Olympic speed skaters.

runningMethods.title: Fartlek (“Speed Play”)
runningMethods.description: Unstructured alternation of faster and slower running within a continuous run, typically over varied terrain.
runningMethods.origin: Invented in Sweden in the 1930s by coach Gösta Holmér.

runningMethods.title: Interval Training (VO₂Max Specific)
runningMethods.description: Structured intervals lasting ~3–5 minutes at high effort near VO₂max, with equal-length recovery periods.
runningMethods.origin: Modern sports training methodologies; widely utilized in field and team sports for aerobic and anaerobic development.

runningMethods.title: Long, Slow Distance (LSD)
runningMethods.description: Extended-duration runs at a low to moderate, steady pace to build aerobic endurance and efficiency.
runningMethods.origin: Founded by German coach/physician Ernst van Aaken and popularized in endurance training practices.

runningMethods.title: Hill Repeats
runningMethods.description: Repeated uphill efforts at high intensity followed by jog or walk recovery downhill—typically for 30 seconds to several minutes per rep—to build strength, power, running economy, and cardiovascular fitness.
runningMethods.origin: Adopted in modern running training as a safe and effective form of speed-strength work for runners of various backgrounds.
